page.title: 19Science
page.content: Pliocene marine formation at St.Erth. G.F.Mitchells findings suggest that the fossils found in the clay suggest that the water depth at the time of the deposition was about l0m.In the north part of the Vicarage Pit the clay survived to a height of 35m;if we add lOm to this we arrive at a minimum figure of 45m (l5O feet) for the height of the sea above its present level in the facility. With regard to the age of the deposit Mitchell concludes whilst the upper most layers are Pleistocene, the underlying clay and sand are almost certainly late Pliocene in age.
